title: How to Make Milk Soup

steps.headline: Pour the milk into a heavy-based saucepan or pot.
Bring to the boil.
Add the flour gradually.
steps.description: It must be gradual, or the flour will form lumps. Stir constantly while adding and after adding.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat to a gentle simmer.
Remove from the heat.
Pour the water and milk into a heavy-based large saucepan or pot.
steps.description: Bring to the boil. Stir constantly (to prevent burning).

steps.headline: Check for a thick layer on the top of the soup.
steps.description: Add the rice. Cook until soft. Stir occasionally.

steps.headline: Add the noodles when the rice is about three quarters cooked through.
Reduce the heat to a gentle warming.
steps.description: Allow the rice and oodles to complete cooking.

steps.headline: Serve hot.
steps.description: This recipe is ideal for feeding a large group of people heartily. Serve with crusty bread.

steps.headline: Make egg batter before starting.
steps.description: Beat the egg with the flour and a pinch of salt. Add a little water or flour to form a batter consistency.

steps.headline: Heat the milk in a heavy-based saucepan or pot.
Add a little butter or oil for flavor.
Pour the egg batter into the boiling milk in a thin stream.
Cook a few more minutes.
steps.description: Serve hot. Can be seasoned with nutmeg, freshly ground black pepper and salt.

steps.headline: Chop the vegetables into bite-size pieces.
Drop the chopped vegetables into the heavy-based saucepan or pot.
Cover with water.
steps.description: Bring to the boil and cook until tender. Add salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Pour in the milk.
steps.description: Bring to the boil, then remove from the heat.

steps.headline: Strain the vegetables out and return to the liquid to the heat.
Thicken with small amounts of cornflour.
steps.description: Add gradually and stir constantly until slightly thickened.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The soup can be served without the vegetables, or you can pile the removed vegetables into the center of the soup and top with a sprig of parsley.

tyn: Stirring implement such as a wooden spoon
Cutting board and knife for some ingredients (optional)
text: Polish milk soup Pour the milk into a heavy-based saucepan or pot. Add the salt and sugar. Bring to the boil.  Add the flour gradually. It must be gradual, or the flour will form lumps. Stir constantly while adding and after adding. Reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Add the butter or oil. Remove from the heat. Serve. Noodle milk soup Pour the water and milk into a heavy-based large saucepan or pot. Bring to the boil. Stir constantly (to prevent burning). Check for a thick layer on the top of the soup. Add the rice. Cook until soft. Stir occasionally. Add the noodles when the rice is about three quarters cooked through.  Reduce the heat to a gentle warming. Allow the rice and oodles to complete cooking. Serve hot. This recipe is ideal for feeding a large group of people heartily. Serve with crusty bread. Egg milk soup Make egg batter before starting. Beat the egg with the flour and a pinch of salt. Add a little water or flour to form a batter consistency. Heat the milk in a heavy-based saucepan or pot.  Add a little butter or oil for flavor.  Pour the egg batter into the boiling milk in a thin stream.  Cook a few more minutes. Serve hot. Can be seasoned with nutmeg, freshly ground black pepper and salt. Vegetable milk soup Chop the vegetables into bite-size pieces.  Drop the chopped vegetables into the heavy-based saucepan or pot.  Cover with water. Bring to the boil and cook until tender. Add salt and pepper to taste. Pour in the milk. Bring to the boil, then remove from the heat. Strain the vegetables out and return to the liquid to the heat. Simmer gently. Thicken with small amounts of cornflour. Add gradually and stir constantly until slightly thickened. Serve. The soup can be served without the vegetables, or you can pile the removed vegetables into the center of the soup and top with a sprig of parsley.
